text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Janet Munro Warner
Present Address: Ste 2 Balcarres Rd Wpg Man
Pioneer Address: Aletown P O Sask
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1894

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? about 10 families

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? twice a year

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? not on Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? no invitations people were friendly then
   What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? at different times when suitable
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? yes
   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) we always had something to eat
   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? a cup of tea

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? mother & family - father didn't like visiting

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? yes
   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. we always looked forward to "bees" of any kind, had lots of possible time

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? describe. perhaps twice a year
   we had a dance houses were pretty small most of them but the odd person had a fair sized house with children
   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. not for while, they changed after war I

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? at first children were young and as they grew up they started taking turns every 2 wks to different neighbors
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back end forth?
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? about 10

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? twice a year not on Sunday

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? not on Sunday

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? at different times when available

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "to make pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?)

We always had something to eat

It no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the children"?

6. Did you ever have these when groups of relations came together to put up a building, make quilting, or other such activities?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, knowing often they occurred.

We always looked forward to these parties

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in houses? describe.

Had a dance Howard went rarely

Had a fan forged house wall oh

Wore those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times - every two weeks, once a week, a month, etc.? at first children were young and

or they grew up who started taking turns
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

We didn't use our school for dancing till after first war

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?).

At the present time schools are used for dances, boxes etc.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Pedro

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Square dances, waltz etc.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

No

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Cards tell after war. In our house we didn't have played & some didn't - 'matter of choice'
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, etc.) If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and make use of the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to play at the schoolhouse?)

At the present time schools are used for dances, dances, dances.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for prizes?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings?

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Couch talk after war I, some of our neighbors played a card deal - matter of choice.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? We didn't bother about gloves etc. in the country.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

There were not too many weddings & all did not have a chivaree.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Things gradually changed as years went on, not much borrowing or drinking as now & no sulphur stick or powder, in fact there was no drinking too far from town & the home brew beer had not started, only 2 French girls used rouge & everybody was disgusted that anyone would appear in public in that form.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality, or "snobbery," do you remember in small towns, such as Clore and later when calling, calling cards, visitors looked especially

13. Were the children known in your community?

Describe what you remember about children, telling how common they were.

There used not too many weddings all did

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember,
telling of any games or entertainments not already mentioned that were popular
at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes
in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Sharp gradually changed as grown-ups no longer

must be invited or drinking was now no longer

for fun among the friends they had now

for Lent only & Friends girls went hang out

organized

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers Local in your community?
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers Club in your district?
When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, their purposes, who joined (mostly young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

different methods, mostly basket socials

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

football & base ball & summertime house shoes - in the snow

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

baseball & play house
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1912, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, its chief purpose (may be religious, social, charitable, etc.), and its membership (if known).

19. What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

20. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

21. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

22. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

23. Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

24. Who provided the lantern and the slides?

25. What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

26. What games did boys play in summer (e.g., baseball, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

27. What games did girls play in summer (e.g., skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

baseball or play house
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *skating*

   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *checkers crocindle dominos*

   Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *every played one*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *after the morning chores were done*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *building snow men*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS.**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *June 1895*

26. Who organized it?  
   *the neighbors*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *all the community, no school at that time*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *no*

   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
   *1893*

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *jumping high & vaulting races of all kinds swings for adults & children also horse racing*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *a long table was set up the trees every body took food which was pooled & was of ever good, one lady kept a store (13) cake for the centre of the table*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *tea*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *about noon & last till dark we drove in wagons a few had a buck board & some rode horse back*
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Feet," "whist," "poker" or others, checkers or other games? 

Was the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children furnish games connected with such things as hunting, bones, arrowheads, graphs or other objects or stories in this manner?

BUILDING AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible. June 1897

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was the first picnic held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? 1895

29. What arrangements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. That did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

One of our bachelors had his collar bone broken & had to be driven in buggy 50 miles to Dr., a dog tripped his horse. Also after that dogs were not allowed at picnics — a girl wore purple hand knit stockings which I always remembered seemed funny to me just arriving from England.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Later on there were booths etc. at picnics. Ice cream, oranges, candy etc. & there were family picnics, 80 picnics.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Baseball races etc. & booths where you can buy lunch don't set tables — just your own group lunch together.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Ladies riding horse back which was very popular in pioneer days. Horse back was when I got around & then I had to herd the cows.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

Still continues

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities — played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Had good baseball team & got uniforms about 1910 & played against neighboring communities. But war changed things.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Outdoor rink for many years.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

None
33. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

One of our neighbors had his cattle in the barnyard. He used to ride his horse around the barnyard. We would often see him there.

34. What changes have you noticed in this place since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Baseball was very popular in the early years. Young people, mostly boys, would play baseball in the community park.

35. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in them.

Basketball was very popular in the early years. Young people, mostly boys, would play basketball in the community park.

36. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

37. How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, skating, etc.).
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).
   generally June or July

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

I don't remember any special books but the minister often gave two books & they we got the travelling Sask Library which was a great help to many

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? yes

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates. yes

48. Was there a school library? yes When was it begun? 1910
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? most of them

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? yes
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   [It grew out of or replaced the earlier community picnic?]
   Who was responsible for starting this first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th). Generally June or July

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible; if not, tell as nearly as you can how many volumes you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

I don't remember any of them, but I know that
the municipal library gave two books which
we got the first year. The library was very
helpful to many.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?
   Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library?
   When was it begun? 1910
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

Generally at post office or some central building. Filled out cards & at end of season I collected 25¢ from each family. This paid transportation. I don't know what they do now or whether they still have a library.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   Family Herald & Weekly Star
   Graham Growers Guide
   New West Farmer

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   No
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them. None

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   Yes at first
   We had no paper as PO was 20 miles but a bachelor loaned us his Tribune.
51. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   In what year did it exist?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contains, how many people have used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

Generally at post office by store and if Hardware store located from each family person transportation by donkey or ox

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? none

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? organ & violin

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. piano

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

We had singing on sunday evenings & still have some in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. We had wonderful concerts

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Scotty songs & jazz

in the community? Kept up with current songs

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. I made parody

63. Was there a band in your community? NO When was it started?

Who started it? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Instruments

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? (Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.)

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your keen entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

[Handwritten note:]
We had some very fine singers but most of them are gone. Also had some very special pianists.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.?
Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

[Handwritten note:]
We used to have a Mr. Mitchell come from Regina for several weeks in summer. He got eggs, birds etc., some are in Regina Museum from Moose Mt.
64. Has anyone from your community been well known or famous in the material world? Give names and dates and places of public appearance.

65. In what was important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the result of these changes?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, sirrhoubls, etc.? If so, describe them.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, raising, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

We used to have a big mitchell cow in summer at the gal. eggs but we never used to have a Regina cow. Some cows are in Regina now.
Oxford.

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.
Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
